Label: academy/university
Scope note: The subject should be used for academies, colleges or universities which are not covered by 'art academy', 'lecture', 'student' or the architecture category 'school/university college'. It should also be used for scenes of university, college life not covered by 'lecture', 'scholar', etc.

Label: acrobat/street-performer
Scope note: If the acrobat is a circus, the term 'circus' should also be entered as a Subject. If on horseback, the term 'equestrian' should also be entered as Subject.

Label: acts of apostles
Scope note: Use when the scene is known to have come from the Biblical text, following Christ's death. Where appropriate (ie. in most cases), double-key with 'saint/martyr'.

Label: acts of mercy
Scope note: Includes the 7 Acts of Mercy (Feeding the hungry, Giving the thirsty to drink, Sheltering strangers, Clothing the naked, Visiting the sick, Visiting or liberating the imprisoned, Burying the dead) and the Spiritual Acts of Mercy (Warning sinners, Informing the ignorant, Advising the vacillating, Consoling the sorrowful, Bearing injustice patiently, Forgiving injuries, Praying for the living and the dead).

Label: agriculture
Scope note: The term is used in the widest sense, following the OED definition: 'The science and art of cultivating the soil; including the allied pursuits of gathering in the crops and rearing live stock; tillage, husbandry, farming (in the widest sense).'

Label: allegory/personification
Scope note: The term is used for images of a subject under the guise of another, such as a personification or emblem representing a concept. Unless the specific type of allegory is listed as one its Narrow Terms, enter the Subject allegory/personification together with another term, the subject of the allegory, such as 'agriculture'. Where appropriate, terms listed as Non-Preferred Terms should be entered as Associated Names. N.B. An additional Subject of deity should be entered for the Roman period for some personifications which were worshipped as deities, e.g. Spes, Fortuna, Salus, etc.

Label: amazonomachy
Scope note: The term is used here to cover various mythological battles involving Amazons and Greeks, sometimes including Greek mythological figures like Herakles and Theseus. Although the most extensive Amazonomachies are on sculptural friezes, they also feature on a variety of objects ranging from gems to sarcophagi. See also the Subject Amazon.

Label: american peoples
Scope note: This term covers all the Americas. If a specific ethnic Name is available, this is entered in Ethnic Name.

Label: ancient history
Scope note: Only used by Prints & Drawings for history up to 323 AD.

Label: anguipede
Scope note: The term refers to a figure with feet or legs in the form of serpents but has also been used to refer to certain giants of ancient mythology. If the term is specified as 'anguipede giant', the Subject term 'titan/giant' should also be entered.

Label: animal-baiting
Scope note: Use for bear-baiting, bull-baiting, cock-fighting, dog-fighting and other sorts of animal fighting arranged for human entertainment.

Label: animal-fighting
Scope note: Use for animals fighting without human intervention. N.B. Enter hunting rather than animal-fighting where appropriate, e.g. for hounds attacking a fox at the end of a hunt.

Label: animal-housing
Scope note: Use for all forms of animal housing (eg. aviary, kennel), apart from farm buildings. Stables are listed individually, unless they form part of a farm, in which case the term 'farm' should be used.

Label: animation/cartoon
Scope note: The term should be used for cartoon characters, such as Mickey Mouse, etc.

Label: anthropomorphic mythical being
Scope note: The term refers to anthropomorphic figures in Western art as a well as to a specific iconographic motif in Nasca art (AMB).

Label: anthropomorphism
Scope note: The term is used for animals portrayed as human beings.

Label: anti-semitism
Scope note: See also 'Jewish' and 'Judaism'.

Label: antiquarian/connoisseur
Scope note: To include collectors.

Label: antiquities
Scope note: The term is used for views of ruins and objects surviving into modern times from the remote past when neither the place nor the type of object (e.g. 'temple' or 'vase') can be identified.

Label: applied/decorative art
Scope note: See also 'trade/industry'.

Label: apsaras
Scope note: Celestial female figure.

Label: archaeology/excavation
Scope note: This term is used for exacavations and archaeological work in progress. For general views of ancient sites, the place name is recorded under topography, and no Subject is necessarily entered. For views of archaeological sites where the emphasis is on a building or structure rather than a general view, the place name is recorded as topography and the Subject is the type of building (e.g. 'temple') if the representation is a good example. For views of unidentified archaeological artefacts, the term 'antiquities' is used.

Label: architectural feature
Scope note: To include details of buildings such as windows, doors, door furniture, chimneys, chimney-piece, chimney-breast, mantelpiece, etc. Only use for elaborate examples.

Label: architecture
Scope note: The subject includes buildings and edifices of any kind, structures and encampments. For interiors of any of the NTs, double-key the relevant term with 'interior'. See also the Object name 'architectural drawing'.

Label: arhat
Scope note: Arhat is a term originally used for the immediate disciples of the Buddha who were expected to very rapidly follow the Buddha into Nirvana, or the Void where there was, at last, no further need for re-incarnation as all karma had worked itself out. The status of the arhats declined somewhat in later Buddhism as they, of course, were mainly concerned with their own salvation, while Mahayana Buddhism laid greater emphasis on ensuring the salvation of other beings. There are many individually named arhats; arhat group paintings are a common subject, and there are portraits of identifiable individual ones as well. The Chinese term is lohan, and the Japanese term is rakan.

Label: armourer
Scope note: The term refers to a maker of armour or weapons.

Label: arms/armour
Scope note: See also 'weapon-smith'.

Label: art academy
Scope note: Includes scenes representing the formal education of artists.

Label: artistic life
Scope note: Use for scenes of activity which are not covered by the NTs, e.g. for artist's assistants preparing materials, or for parodies such as animals painting, etc.

Label: arts and sciences
Scope note: The term is used for personifications of the Liberal Arts and other Arts and Sciences. For non-allegorical use of the terms, see Arts/Architecture and Science.

Label: arts/architecture
Scope note: See also narrower terms of ART and ARCHITECTURE.

Label: ashinaga
Scope note: Mythical Chinese fisherman 'Long Legs'.

Label: asian mythical figure/creature
Scope note: This term is used for all mythical or mythological figures or creatures in Asian mythology. One of its Narrow Terms is a Broad Term in its own right, Indian mythological figure/creature, the others are a list of simple terms.

Label: astrology
Scope note: For personifications of Astrology, the term 'arts and sciences' is used. See also 'myth/legend' and its Narrow Terms.

Label: athlete
Scope note: The term is used here in its original sense as being a competitor in physical exercises including athletics, boxing, wrestling, etc. To retrieve images of an athlete in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' should be included in the search.

Label: athletics/running
Scope note: The term is for images of athletics and people running races, in a competitive or general context. If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

Label: audience/assembly
Scope note: For events which do not fall under 'ceremony' but are formal occasions such as meetings, councils, or interviews granted by royalty, the clergy, government, etc.

Label: australian/indigenous australian
Scope note: See also the Ethnic Name 'Indigenous Australian'.

Label: bag
Scope note: This term is used when the bag is of significance in the image.

Label: baku
Scope note: Eaters of bad dreams and nightmares in Japanese legend.

Label: ballooning
Scope note: Including barage balloons.

Label: bamboo
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance (e.g. an attribute of a boddhisattva).

Label: banner
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: baramasa
Scope note: This term refers to sets of works that usually each consist of 10 paintings. These 'songs of the seasons' visualise the month and seasons of the year. The main theme represented is the visualisation of lovers; their love in union and in separation is represented as the different months of the year.

Label: barrack/camp scene
Scope note: To include bivouacs, encampments, etc. in a military context.

Label: basket/basketry
Scope note: This term is used when the basket or basketry are of significance in the image.

Label: bathing
Scope note: Use the term when the emphasis is on the activity of bathing, rather than, e.g., a beach scene. This covers both bathing as washing and bathing for recreation.

Label: battle
Scope note: See also the Subject 'massacre'.

Label: battleship
Scope note: To include battlecruisers, frigates, destroyers etc.

Label: bhairava raga
Scope note: One of the elements of the ragamala system.

Label: bhairavi ragini
Scope note: The imagined consort of Bhairava Raga, one of the elements of the Ragamala system.

Label: bible
Scope note: On the broadest level, this subject covers scenes from the Bible and pious images, which have their own Subject headings.

Label: bijin
Scope note: Literally 'beautiful woman' in Japanese art, most commonly seen in ukiyo-e paintings and prints of courtesans, geisha or ordinary townswomen; occasionally for images of young male prostitutes.

Label: bird's eye view/long view
Scope note: The term refers to views seen from a height. See also PANORAMA.

Label: black
Scope note: The nationality (where known) should be entered as an additional Subject term, e.g. for black Americans. When searching for images of black people of any nationality, search also for subject 'African'.

Label: blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: book/newspaper
Scope note: For scenes connected with the production and use of books and newspapers.

Label: boxing/boxer
Scope note: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

Label: brothel/brothel-keeper
Scope note: If there is an emphasis on prostitutes in the scene, the additional term 'courtesan/prostitute' is included in the Subject field.

Label: bucranium
Scope note: The term refers to an ox or bull skull used as a decorative motif, possibly with amuletic or symbolic meaning.

Label: buddhapada
Scope note: The footprints of the Buddha.

Label: buddhist council
Scope note: Buddhist councils started to be held after the Parinirvana of the Buddha to preserve the Buddha's teachings and monastic rules.

Label: cakra
Scope note: The term refers to a wheel or discus like symbol which is commonly used in Buddhist, Hindu and Jain iconography.

Label: cakravartin
Scope note: A world leader in ancient Indian lore. Enter the name of the caktavartin, if known, in Associated Name.

Label: calendar
Scope note: The term is also an object name. Double-key if relevant.

Label: calligraphy
Scope note: The term 'calligraphy' is also an Object Name, for works described as 'calligraphy', especially in the Asia and Middle East departments.

Label: callot figure
Scope note: The term refers to a particular type of diminutive human figure which appears in the 18thC in the fine and decorative arts. Although described as Callot figures, they differ substantially from the work of Jacques Callot. See G. B. Bauer and H. Verfonern, 'Barocke Zwergenkarikaturen von Callot bis Chodowiecki', exhib. cat., Salzburg, Galerie der Stadt, 1991.

Label: canopy
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

Label: card-playing
Scope note: Double key with 'gambling' if necessary. Also use for designs for playing-cards (P&D only). Actual playing-cards should be entered as such in the object name field.

Label: caricature
Scope note: The term is restricted to portraits. See also satire.

Label: carnival
Scope note: Used traditionally for the festival held immediately before Lent, particularly in Venice; often used in calendars to illustrate February

Label: castle/fort
Scope note: This term is used to describe fortified buildings, including feudal castles. Grand houses, such as French châteaux, are indexed as 'palace/mansion'. Where appropriate both terms may be used, e.g. for Windsor Castle or the Tower of London.

Label: catholicism
Scope note: Theterm is also used for anti-catholic subjects.

Label: centauromachy
Scope note: The term is used here to cover general battles between Centaurs and Greeks (usually Lapiths). See also the Subjects Centaur and Lapith.

Label: ceramic
Scope note: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for ceramics.

Label: ceremonial dress
Scope note: The term is restricted to the Department of Africa, Oceania and Americas collection.

Label: charioteer/chariot
Scope note: The term 'charioteer/chariot' is used for images of charioteers or chariots or both where the context is not chariot-racing (for which use the term 'charioteer/chariot-racing'). If the chariot is being driven by a deity, emperor, soldier, personification, etc. an additional Subject term should be entered.

Label: charioteer/chariot-racing
Scope note: Use this term for charioteers or chariots or both in a chariot-racing context, even if the race itself is not depicted, such as victors being crowned. See also 'prize-giving' and 'circus/hippodrome'. For charioteers or chariots in other contexts, use 'charioteer/chariot'.

Label: cherry blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had iconographic significance.

Label: cherub/cupid
Scope note: This term should not be used as a Subject in P&D.

Label: child
Scope note: In P&D, restricted to scenes representing childhood activities (apart from 'school' and 'sport/pastime' which should be used instead) and for child labour.

Label: child art
Scope note: For works by artists when children.

Label: chimaera
Scope note: A grotesque monster, formed of the parts of various animals.

Label: christ
Scope note: Use only for pious images, not in a biblical setting. Images of Christ may be found under the Narrow Terms of `Christ', `New Testament' or 'God Father'.

Label: christ as man of sorrows
Scope note: Use when Christ is shown with the Instruments of the Passion, not in a Biblical setting.

Label: christ child
Scope note: Use for pious images, not in a biblical setting.

Label: christ majesty
Scope note: Christ in Majesty.

Label: christ on the cross
Scope note: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting. Do not confuse with 'Crucifixion'; see notes under 'Passion'.

Label: christian sect
Scope note: The term is used for systems of belief differing from the orthodox traditions; sometimes applied specifically to groups that are regarded as heretical.

Label: chrysanthemum blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: church
Scope note: Use this term for cathedrals, chapels, etc.

Label: cintamani
Scope note: In Buddhist iconography, this is a flaming jewel which is supposed to grant all wishes to the wearer.

Label: circus performance
Scope note: This term applies to performances, and additional Subject terms such as ‘acrobat/street performer’, 'clown', ‘equestrian’, etc. should be added as necessary. The term should also be entered for views of travelling circuses, including tents and equipment.

Label: circus/hippodrome
Scope note: The circus was a long rectangular structure where Roman chariot racing events took place. The hippodrome was a long rectangular area where in Greek times, chariot and horse races were staged, often with little if any architecture but sometimes with banks of earth for the spectators to stand on, and its use continued down into Roman times. Some well-known Roman examples include the Circus of Maxentius (Circus of Caracalla), the Circus Maximus and the Circus Flavinius. See also the terms 'Roman amphitheatre/arena', 'classical theatre/odeon' and 'classical stadium'. N.B. The Stadium of Domitian, also known as the 'Circo Aragonale', and sometimes as the 'Circus of Domitian', was a stadium, not a circus.

Label: cistern
Scope note: See also the term 'water supply'.

Label: civic building
Scope note: Includes town halls, etc. See also meeting space/ceremonial ground.

Label: classical costume
Scope note: Includes examples of simulated classical costume.

Label: classical deity
Scope note: Certain figures in classical mythology, e.g. Herakles (Hercules), are considered as both a classical deity and classical mythological figure and these two Subjects should be entered in such cases. The 'classical deity' includes syncretic deities combining attributes of classical and non-classical deities.

Label: classical mythological figure/creature
Scope note: In some cases a Narrow Term of 'classical mythological figure' is also the name of an individual, recorded in the Associated Name field. Examples include: sibyl and Cumean Sibyl', 'triton and 'Triton', 'amazon' and 'Amazon', etc. Certain figures in classical mythology, e.g. Herakles (Hercules), are considered as both a classical deity and classical mythological figure and these two Subjects should be entered in such cases.

Label: classical mythology
Scope note: The term classical mythology is used for scenes of classical mythology. If the main subject of the image is a classical deity, mythological figure or mythical creature, the Subjects 'classical deity' or 'classical mythological figure/creature' (or its Narrow Terms) are used instead of 'classical mythology', and their individual names, when known, are entered in Associated Name. N.B. Some named mythological figures or creatures (Biographical Authority entries and Associated Name field) have become generic terms (Subject field) as well, e.g. Nereid, Triton, and a nereid or triton, etc. If those named individuals are recorded in Associated Name, the Subject term equivalent has to be entered as well, but not vice-versa.

Label: classical sport
Scope note: The term encompasses the athletic contests, exercise and spectacles which took place in the Greek and Roman world. Before such events became part of major games festivals and entertainment, they were often part of funeral rituals, with the contests originally held to decide who should inherit the possessions of the deceased. A variety of events, many of which are not exclusive to the Classical World, were involved. In addition to the five major games festivals held at Olympia, Delphi, Nemea, Corinth and the Isthmus, there were hundreds of minor sports festivals. All tended to have the same core events: running, the pentathlon (running, discus, javelin, long jump, wrestling), combat events (boxing, wrestling, the pankration) and equestrian events (chariot and bare-back racing), with a variety of additions. From the surviving depictions we cannot know whether a particular festival is being represented, but because the core events were common to nearly all the games we can use them as generic representations of these sports. For example, no depictions survive that we can directly associate with the ancient Olympics but athletic and equestrian scenes on vases, the bulk of which were produced in Athens, can nonetheless be used to illustrate the type of events that were staged at the Olympics. By Roman times sports contests, especially gladiatorial combat and chariot racing, were increasingly employed as entertainment. See ‘amphitheatre/arena’, ‘palaistra/gymnasium’, ‘stadium’. If a sport is depicted in the context of classical sport, but the Subject term for it is not included as a Narrow Term here (e.g. athletics), the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is added.

Label: classical stadium
Scope note: The term applies to a Greek or Roman long, rectangular structure, sometimes with banks or seats for viewing, purpose-built for athletic contests. .See also the term 'circus/hippodrome'. N.B. The Stadium of Domitian, also known as the 'Circo Aragonale', and sometimes as the 'Circus of Domitian', was a stadium, not a circus.

Label: classical theatre/odeon
Scope note: In Greek and Roman cultures, a theatre was a building purpose-built for housing dramatic performances and contests, whereas an odeon was a roofed building used for musical performances. Some well-known examples of theatres include those at Ephesus, Epidaurus, Herculaneum, Jerash, Miletus, Rome (Theatre of Marcellus), Pompeii (the 'Great' or 'large' theatre), Syracuse, Taormina. The Odeon at Pompeii is sometimes referred to as the 'small theatre’ or occasionally as the ‘covered theatre'. See also the term 'Roman amphitheatre/arena'.

Label: cleric
Scope note: Includes priests, vicars, cardinals, bishops, rabbis, mullas, etc.

Label: clown
Scope note: If the clown is in a circus, the term 'circus' should also be entered as a Subject. If on horseback, the term 'equestrian' should also be entered as Subject.

Label: collage/mixed media
Scope note: The term is used for depictions of collages or works in mixed media, not for the objects themselves.

Label: colourman
Scope note: Artists' colourman: dealer in artists' materials

Label: concert
Scope note: The term should also be used for recitals, including informal events performed in a domestic setting..

Label: construction
Scope note: Double-key with whatever is being built. Use also for repair and rebuilding of architecture or structures such as bridges.

Label: container
Scope note: This term is used when the container is of significance in the image.

Label: cosmetics
Scope note: The term includes any form of of make-up and also patches used in the 17thC and 18thC in Europe as a fashionable ornament for faces.

Label: costume/clothing
Scope note: Double-key with other terms in the thesaurus as necessary, e.g. 'baker'. See also Object Name 'costume print' and Subject 'personal ornament'. This category and its NTs should be used very sparingly, for very detailed examples of costume.

Label: courtesan/prostitute
Scope note: If the image includes a brothel or brothel-keeper, the additional term 'brothel/brothel-keeper' is included in the Subject field. See also 'kamuro'.

Label: courtship/love
Scope note: This subject is very broad and covers all aspects of romantic love, courtship, elopement, etc. See also the Subject terms: marriage/wedding', 'married life', and 'eroticism/pornography'.

Label: craftsman/maker
Scope note: See also 'metalworker'. The term 'jeweller' is s search term for 'craftsman/maker' rather than 'metalworker' as not all jewellery is made of metal.

Label: crucifixion
Scope note: Do not confuse with 'Christ on Cross'. See note under `Passion'.

Label: dairy
Scope note: The term refers to a place where milk and cream are kept, and made into butter and cheese, and also includes the use of the term to designate a shop in which milk, cream, etc. are sold.

Label: dairy-farming
Scope note: The term refers to the production of milk, butter and cheese. For representations of dairy buildings, the term 'dairy' should be used. When the emphasis is on people milking, the the combined term 'milkmaid/dairyman' should be used for European scenes, and 'herder' for non-European scenes.

Label: death
Scope note: Only use the actual term 'Death' for memento mori, death-bed scenes, death-masks, and any allegorical representations such as the Dance of Death, etc.

Label: death of sakyamuni
Scope note: The final transition of Sakyamuni to the enlightened state. Iconographically represented by the buddha lying on his side, surrounded by his followers, including Ananda. Before he abandoned his body to the deathless state of nirvana, he told his followers not to keep relics. And so the body was cremated. However, relics were retained and placed in stupas.

Label: deity
Scope note: If the main Subject is a classical deity the Subject term deity is used instead of classical mythology, and the individual name is entered in Associated Name. See also classical mythology.

Label: demolition
Scope note: Double-key with whatever is being demolished.

Label: dikpala
Scope note: A guardian of a specific direction (North, North-East, etc.) in Hindu and Buddhist art.

Label: disciple
Scope note: This does not refer to the Twelve disciples of Christ, but rather to the more general use of the term.

Label: discus
Scope note: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered. See also the term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

Label: dockyard/shipyard
Scope note: The terms refer to large enclosures, adjoining the sea or a river, in which ships are built or repaired. (OED).

Label: domestic life
Scope note: The term is for family scenes and scenes in a home setting, e.g. people engaged in domestic activities and chores. See also servant/domestic worker.

Label: draughtsman/painter
Scope note: The term is used for amateur as well as professional artists.

Label: drugs
Scope note: The term is restricted to recreational drugs. For the medical context, see 'medicine'.

Label: duel
Scope note: See also the Subject 'single combat'.

Label: eight days of the week
Scope note: Very important in mainland Southeast Asia for horoscopes, etc. Each day of the week is assigned an animal, Wednesday is divided in two.

Label: eight precious things
Scope note: These include: artemesia leaf, rhinoceros horns, books, stone chime, mirror, lozenge, golden coin and dragon pearl.

Label: eight treasures of buddhism
Scope note: These include: endless knot, wheel of the Law, conch shell, parasol, canopy, lotus, lidded jar and paired fish. This term should be entered in all cases where all, of only some, of the items listed here occur in this context. In the case of lotus, (paired) fish, enter these terms as well.

Label: elder
Scope note: The term is used here in the sense of a tribal elder, and not in the sense of a Christian minister (or any other use of the term).

Label: elements
Scope note: Earth, Air, Fire and Water.

Label: emperor/empress
Scope note: Use when the emphasis is on the individual, not the scene. This term should not be used in P&D records.

Label: encountering hardship
Scope note: Sakyamundi's father did everything he could to protect his son and to ensure that he would become a great king. A great wall was built around the palace, and all negative influences were kept away from the young prince. The prince was happy and successful. He married and had a child. However, one day he decided to leave the palace to see his people. During this visit he encountered old age, sickness and death for the first time. He was profoundly moved, and the compassion within him led him to want to bring an end to the suffering.

Label: equestrian
Scope note: Use this term when the subject is not covered by the narrow or related terms, e.g.: for horseman hacking, in dressage, or in a more general context.

Label: eroticism/sex
Scope note: This term should be used for all subjects connected with consenting sex or lasciviousness. See also molestation/assault.

Label: fair
Scope note: This subject covers village or country fairs and fêtes as well as funfairs. It should also be used for the rides or structures present at such events, or in public playgrounds, such as merry-go-rounds, etc. See also the Subject 'fête champêtre'.

Label: farmer/farm worker
Scope note: The Subject covers people owning and working on their farms, and those employed to work on farms.

Label: farming
Scope note: The term should be used for farming scenes, with emphasis on the activity. See also: 'farmer' and 'farm building/farmyard'.

Label: fighting/brawling
Scope note: The term is used for street brawls, domestic violence, etc.

Label: figure study
Scope note: P&D: restrict, in the main, to artists by whom the Department has a lot of drawings and who are better known for another type of work. Use sparingly for exceptional examples by other artists.

Label: fireworks/illuminations
Scope note: For temporary architecture erected for firework displays, see 'temporary architecture'.

Label: first sermon of sakyamuni
Scope note: Sakyamuni gave his first sermon in the deer park of Benares. Iconographically, this event is often depicted as two deer, one on either side of a wheel. The wheel represents both the dharma that is teaching and the cosmos, the Buddha being both the universal cosmic monarch and the teacher of the path to enlightenment.

Label: fisherman/fishing
Scope note: The term should be used for all types of fishing including whaling, whether sporting, commercial or subsistence.

Label: flowers of the four seasons
Scope note: Prunus, chrysanthemum, lotus and peony.

Label: food preservation
Scope note: Use for images of drying, smoking, pickling food for storage etc.

Label: fool/jester
Scope note: The term 'clown ' is used for circus clowns.

Label: foreigner
Scope note: The term is restricted to Japanese iconography, where it has the specific meaning of imagery relating to foreigners associated with the ports of Nagasaki and Yokohama, etc.

Label: fountain
Scope note: See also the term 'water supply'.

Label: fungus
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

Label: furniture/woodwork
Scope note: Restricted to detailed examples or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for furniture or woodwork.

Label: fuzoku
Scope note: Fuzoku is a Japanese term for 'genre scenes'.

Label: fête champêtre
Scope note: Fête champêtre is a term used to describe the depiction of figures enjoying pleasures in an open-air setting. The theme can first be identified in 16th-century Italian art, notably in Venice in the paintings of Giorgione and Titian, although the term fête champêtre was not applied at the time. Its development can be traced through to the 18th century when a variant, known as the fête galante, practised principally by French artists (notably Antoine Watteau, Nicolas Lancret and Jean-Baptiste Pater), gained popularity as a genre. Subsequently, from the early 19th century the term fête champêtre was increasingly applied to the earlier Italian works and to the theme as a whole.

Label: gajasimha
Scope note: Lion-elephant.

Label: gambling/gaming
Scope note: To include gambling, betting, wagering. Double-key with card-playing, etc., as necessary. For prizes awarded in contests, see 'prize-giving'.

Label: garment
Scope note: This term should be used for noteworthy individual items of clothing. See also ceremonial dress and other subcategories of costume/clothing.

Label: gathering
Scope note: Use for community and formal gatherings - do not use for small gatherings, such as family meals.

Label: gigantism/dwarfism
Scope note: The term refers to people of unusually large or small size; for mythical beings, see 'titan/giant' and 'ogre/giant'. For any named giant, enter the name in Associated Name.

Label: gigantomachy
Scope note: The term is used here to refer to the general battle between the Olympian gods and the Titans (often referred to as Giants). See also Subjects deity and Titan.

Label: gladiatorial combat
Scope note: The term is used in preference to 'gladiator' when a combat is shown.

Label: glass
Scope note: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for glass.

Label: glass production
Scope note: To include glass-blowing.

Label: god the father and the holy spirit
god the father with christ and saints
grass
Scope note: Use in JA only, for detailed depictions.

Label: great departure
Scope note: The Buddha decided to renounce his life in the palace and become and ascetic in the hope of ending suffering. One night he quietly left the palace, leaving his parents, wife, and child. He took his white horse, and it is said that the four heavenly kings held the four hooves of his horse so that they would not make noise and wake the palace guards.

Label: grisette
Scope note: The term refers to particular type of Parisian working woman in the eighteenth century..

Label: guardian
Scope note: This term refers to a figure in Asian religious art.

Label: gymnasium/palaistra
Scope note: The terms 'gymnasium' and 'palaistra' refer to facilities where exercise and athletic competitions took place in classical times. Combat events such as boxing and wrestling were a speciality of the Greek 'palaistra', whereas the Roman 'palaestra' was an exercise area attached to public baths.

Label: haiku
Scope note: Japanese seventeen syllable poem.

Label: harem
Scope note: If an interior is shown double-key with INTERIOR.

Label: harness/trappings
Scope note: This Subject should only be used when the emphasis of the image is on the objects.

Label: harpy
Scope note: The term refers to a fabulous monster with a woman's face and body, and a bird's wings and claws.

Label: headgear/hairstyle
Scope note: Includes wigs. Double-key as necessary with specific costume.

Label: hell
Scope note: Also enter Hades or Hell in Associated Place.

Label: hinduism
Scope note: The term is used for illustrations of the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Life of K???a, Jaimini Bharata, Markandeya Purana, etc.

Label: hintha bird
Scope note: The hintha bird is a Burmese version of the ancient Indian hamsa bird. In both contexts, it is associated with royalty. The hintha bird is the symbol of the city of Pegu.

Label: history
Scope note: For P&D, do not use this term in the Subject field; use its narrow terms, or for historical events after 1453, the Historical Event field. See also the satire category for satirical drawings.

Label: holy family
Scope note: Use for scenes with the three figures of Mary, Joseph, and Christ Child only, and where not in a biblical setting. See also note under `Nativity'.

Label: holy family with baptist
Scope note: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

Label: holy family with god the father
holy family with saints
Scope note: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

Label: holy family with st anne
Scope note: Use for pious images, not in a Biblical setting. See also note under `Nativity'.

Label: horse-racing
Scope note: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered.

Label: house of loreto
Scope note: Only to be used in connection with our lady of loreto

Label: human remains
Scope note: The term is used for images of actual human remains rather than the Nasca 'trophy head' motif, or allegorical or satirical images of human remains.

Label: humour
Scope note: Double-key with subject of the humour.

Label: hunting/shooting
Scope note: The term should be used for all types of hunting and shooting, whether sporting, commercial or subsistence.

Label: hut/thatched building
Scope note: The term is for recording examples of huts in non-western contexts, often used as dwellings or as meeting-places, or having another social significance. It is not intended for beach-huts, outbuildings, etc. In many instances, it is not possible to determine the intended use of a hut or thatched building, ie. whether domestic or not. Anyone interested in representations of domestic buildings should therefore also include this category in their searches.

Label: imperial court
Scope note: Other terms, such as 'ceremony/procession', 'festival', etc., should be added as additional Subject terms as necessary. The term itself should not be used in P&D.

Label: industrial building
Scope note: A mint is both the institution responsible for making coins and the industrial building where the processes happen. As most of the buildings reresented are for the industrial buildings, 'mint' is a Non-Preferred Term for 'industrial building'.

Label: interior
Scope note: The Subject term recording the type of building is added in addition to the term 'interior' (e.g.: 'civic building').

Label: javelin
Scope note: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical sport' is entered.

Label: jewellery
Scope note: The term 'personal ornament' is often used in preference to 'jewellery' in non-European contexts. Searches on the Broader Term 'personal ornament' will provide the broadest results.

Label: jewish
Scope note: The term is used for images characterising Jewish people, rather than for every image of someone who happens to be Jewish; see also judaism and anti-semitism. For images of rabbis, see 'cleric'.

Label: judaism
Scope note: The term is used for Jewish religious subjects; see also Jewish and anti-semitism. For images of rabbis, see 'cleric'.

Label: judgement of christ
Scope note: To include judgement by priest, Herod, or Pilate.

Label: juhachiban
Scope note: The eighteen favourite roles of the kabuki actor Ichikawa Danjuro.

Label: kabuki
Scope note: For scenes from plays; use 'theatre/opera house' for the buildings. Double-key with 'actor' and enter other actors' names, play details, etc. in the Associated fields as necessary.

Label: kamuro
Scope note: A kamuro is a child attendant to a courtesan in Japan. See also 'courtesan'.

Label: kinnara/kinnari
Scope note: The term refers to half human, half bird creatures (kinnara - male; kinnari - female) known for their faithfulness to their spouse.

Label: kitchen
Scope note: Although some images of kitchens do not relate to interiors, the term 'kitchen' is under the Broad term 'interior' as that is the context in most instances.

Label: kosode/furisode
Scope note: Furisode are extra wide sleeves on young women's kimono, indicative of unmarried status. Conversely, kosode are narrow sleeves on women's kimono, indicative of married status.

Label: krishna-lila
Scope note: The term refers to the divine play (lila) of the god K???a.

Label: kyoka
Scope note: Japanese thirty one syllable comic poem, known as 'crazy' or 'mad' verse.

Label: labourer/manual worker
Scope note: This term should be used for manual workers, other than agricultural workers. See also 'agricultural worker' and its Narrow Terms and other Narrow Terms of 'trade/occupation'.

Label: lamentation
Scope note: Do not confuse with `Pieta'. See note under Passion.

Label: lamp/candle
Scope note: Use the subject term when the emphasis is on the depiction of the object.

Label: landscape
Scope note: For JA, LANDSCAPE includes coastal views. P&D: restrict this term, in the main, to artists by whom the Department has a lot of drawings or prints and who are better known for another type of work. Use sparingly for exceptional examples by other artists.

Label: landscaped garden
Scope note: Includes jardins anglais.

Label: legal building
Scope note: For the interior, the term 'law-court' is used.

Label: library
Scope note: The term should be used for any kind of library. If the library is building attached to a school, university or college, the additional term 'school/university/college building' should also be entered as a Subject.

Label: life of baptist
Scope note: To exclude any scenes involving Christ.

Label: lifeboat
Scope note: For scenes with lifeboats in action.

Label: linga
Scope note: The term refers to the aniconic form of the god Siva, depicted as a standing phallic column. It is also an Object Name for sculptures in the shape of a linga. The Associated Name ?iva should also be entered.

Label: literature
Scope note: Not used by Prints & Drawings.

Label: lokapala
Scope note: A guardian of one of the Four Quarters of Space in Hindu and Buddhist iconography.

Label: lotus
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance.

Label: lotus blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: lotus throne
Scope note: The throne, pedestal or seat in which the Buddha is often represented seated.

Label: love allegorical
Scope note: Use for allegorical representations of Love.

Label: magnolia blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: mantra
Scope note: Syllables believed to have special religious and protective power.

Label: maple and water
Scope note: This is a traditional Japanese motif, based on a poem.

Label: market/bazaar
Scope note: See also the terms 'fair' and 'shop'.

Label: marriage/wedding
Scope note: See also the term 'kosode/furisode'.

Label: married life
Scope note: To include domestic marital scenes, also cuckoldry, divorce, etc.

Label: mask
Scope note: The term 'mask' is to be used for noteworthy depictions of any type of mask, apart from theatrical masks, which have their own entry..

Label: masquerade/party
Scope note: See also fête champêtre.

Label: massacre
Scope note: See also the Subject 'Massacre of the Innocents'.

Label: medicine man/shaman
Scope note: Shaman is a Siberian term from the Evenk, used and misused extensively in North America and elsewhere in the world as a concrete category.

Label: medicine/health
Scope note: This category includes 'alternative' medicine and treatments.

Label: medieval history
Scope note: Prints & Drawings only. For history between 323 AD and 1453.

Label: meeting space/ceremonial ground
Scope note: A meeting space, at which religious ceremonies and/or social functions are carried out. In Polynesia the space incorporates built structures (whether building or stepped platforms) as well as exterior space, usually delineated by a boundary wall or fence. See also civic building.

Label: metalwork
Scope note: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for metalwork.

Label: metalworker
Scope note: The term refers to most types of metalworkers, but there are separate entries for 'armourer', 'blacksmith/farrier' and 'goldsmith/jeweller' which are Narrow Terms.

Label: military
Scope note: See also the Subject 'massacre'.

Label: military/naval
Scope note: This includes the Subject 'Merchant Navy'.

Label: milkmaid/dairyman
Scope note: The terms refers to people milking, working in dairies or otherwise involved in selling dairy produce. For non-European contexts, use herdsman if appropriate.

Label: mill/grindstone
Scope note: For industrial mills, use 'industrial building'.

Label: mint worker
Scope note: The term refers here to images of people engaged in coin production, including engravers, assayers, people strking coins, etc.

Label: mitate/yatsushi
Scope note: The term refers to a representation in Japanese art in which two normally unconnected phenomena are playfully linked. Sometimes translated as 'parody'. Yatsushi is a related, but narrower term, which specifically refers to cases in which scenes from the past are impersonated in modern dress.

Label: modern stadium/arena
Scope note: The term is for modern stadia and arena, often for not exclusively in the context of sporting events. See also 'classical stadium'.

Label: money/currency
Scope note: For depictions of misers, see the Description field.

Label: monument
Scope note: The additional subject 'sculpture' should be added as necessary.

Label: motor vehicle
Scope note: Use more specific terms where possible.

Label: myth/legend
Scope note: See also 'astrology' and its Narrow Terms.

Label: naga/nagini
Scope note: Cobra (Sanskrit). In Indian iconography, there is a group of minor deities who have a snake form. The king of the snake deities is nagaraja, female snake deities are nagini, the snake festival is Nagapancami. In Buddhist mythology, there are several named nagas, one of whom is the nagaraja Apalala, another is Mucalinda.

Label: nat
Scope note: Nats are spirits in the Burmese belief system the need to be propitiated so that they do not cause harm. Some nats occupy natural features, such as trees and bodies of water, and others are part of a more formal system called the Thirty-seven Lords. The latter are named individuals who died violent (‘green’) deaths, and around whom a whole mythology has developed. In addition to small offerings, the nats are also celebrated in periodic festivals called ‘nat pwe’ where mediums are possessed by the spirits. Belief in nats probably pre-dates the arrival of Buddhism in Burma during the first millennium of the common era.

Label: nationality/peoples
Scope note: The Narrow Terms of this Subject are used for images that comment on, rather than merely represent, national or cultural characteristics. See also the Subject costume/clothing and its Narrow Terms and the Ethnic Name field.

Label: native north american
Scope note: If the specific Ethnic Name is available, it is entered in that field. See also 'Native North American' and its Narrow Terms in Ethnic Name for drawings, paintings and photographs of portraits in the Department of AOA representing Native North American people.

Label: nativity
Scope note: Certain representations which are pious images, not portrayed in a Biblical setting, should not be keyed under `Nativity' but rather under the relevant narrow term of the 'Christ' category. An example is `Holy Family' (narrow term of `Christ') versus `Nativity' (narrow term of `Birth of Christ').

Label: naumachia
Scope note: Naumachia is the term (originally Greek) for a sea battle, but became used also for the purpose built venues for such battles.

Label: navagraha
Scope note: The term refers to an astrological theme in South and Southeast Asia.

Label: new testament
Scope note: See categories 'Christ' and 'Virgin' for pious images, not in a Biblical setting.

Label: no
Scope note: Japanese drama.

Label: non-conformist
Scope note: For specific examples other than those listed as narrower terms, use 'non-conformist'. The term should also be used for scenes of non-conformist activity, and should be double-keyed with the 'preacher/evangelist' term when a preacher is non-conformist.

Label: ogre/giant
Scope note: The subject is restricted to creatures of folklore and myth; the Subject 'titan/giant' is used for classical giants. For any named giant, the name is entered in Associated Name.

Label: our lady of fatima
Scope note: Records must have Fatima in Associated place as well as Virgin in Associated Name. Subject blank.

Label: our lady of good counsel
Scope note: Problem - leave.

Label: our lady of good counsel of praia
Scope note: Nossa Senhora da Conceicao da Praia. Problem - leave

Label: our lady of hope
Scope note: Use English for "N. D. D'ESPERANCE".

Label: our lady of san juan de los lagos
our lady of sceaux
Scope note: The alternative name used in inscriptions is "SCEX".

Label: our lady of the abandoned
Scope note: Nostra Senora de dos Desamparados.

Label: our lady of the angels
Scope note: Originally associated with St Francis of Assisi and the chapel of Our Lady of the Angels in Poriuncula (near Assisi, Italy).

Label: our lady of the blessed scapular
our lady of the morning star
our lady of the pine tree
our lady of the rosary of fatima
our lady of the rosary of pompei
our lady of the sacred heart
our lady of the seven sorrows
our lady of vallicella
Scope note: Miraculous icon at the Chiesa Nuova in Rome for which Rubens designed an altarpiece.

Label: our lady of virtue
Scope note: Associated with Notre Dame des Vertus at Aubervilliers (Seine).

Label: our lady of walsingham
Scope note: Shrine of the Mystery of the Incarnation; also referred to as Heavenly Empress.

Label: our lady star of the sea
painter/decorator
Scope note: Use for external (e.g. house painters) and internal decorators.

Label: palace/mansion
Scope note: The term is used for grand houses. Where these are fortified, e.g. Windsor Castle, the term castle/fort may also be used.

Label: panorama
Scope note: This term is restricted to designs for 19thC 360º panorama, or drawings connected with them.

Label: parable of wise and foolish virgins
Scope note: Matthew 25:1-13

Label: paradise
Scope note: In Asia, where it represents several paradises associated with different buddhas.

Label: parliament
Scope note: Includes the Opening of Parliament.

Label: passion
Scope note: Certain representations, which are pious images, not portrayed in a Biblical setting, should not be keyed under a narrow term of `Passion', but rather under a narrow term of the `Christ' category. An example is `Christ on Cross' (narrow term of `Christ') versus `Crucifixion' (narrow term of `Passion').

Label: peach blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: peasant/villager
Scope note: The term is used for scenes with country people, other than specifically agricultural subjects for which other Subjects are used (e.g. 'ploughing'). Tavern scenes, markets and festivals are entered as additional Subjects.

Label: pell-mell
Scope note: Also known as Pall-Mall. Game with a ball and mallet played in an alley.

Label: peony blossom
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: personal accessory
Scope note: Restricted to detailed examples, or designs, for fans, etc. See also Object Name field.

Label: personal-ornament
Scope note: The term 'personal ornament' is often used in preference to 'jewellery' in non-European contexts. Searches on the Broader Term 'personal ornament' will provide the broadest results. See also 'personal ornament'.

Label: phoenix
Scope note: 'Simurgh' is the Persian term for a type of phoenix.

Label: physical condition
Scope note: This term should only be used for unusual physical conditions, e.g. conjoined twins or extremely tall, small, obese, etc. people. Such people were exhibited in fairs, etc. until the early 20thC.

Label: pieta
Scope note: Use for images of the Dead Christ with Mary, when a pious image, not in a Biblical setting.

Label: pleasure garden
Scope note: In Europe, the term refers to gardens created as commercial resorts for city-dwellers, of the type popular from the 17th to the middle of the 19th century, e.g. Vauxhall Gardens in London, Tivoli in Copenhagen.

Label: pleasure quarters
Scope note: Pleasure quarters refer to areas with brothels, tea houses and theatres, ie. general entertainment areas.

Label: plum blossom/tree
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it had special significance.

Label: political propaganda
Scope note: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, in this case political. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

Label: politician/statesman
Scope note: The term includes all members of national and local government.

Label: politics
Scope note: See also satire category for satirical drawings and prints.

Label: priestess
Scope note: A female priest of a non-Christian religion.

Label: prince/princess
Scope note: This term should not be used in P&D records.

Label: printmaking/printing
Scope note: This term covers the production of both prints and printed text.

Label: prison
Scope note: To include scenes of captivity.

Label: prisoner
Scope note: To include captives.

Label: prize-giving
Scope note: The term refers to the representation of the act of prize-giving, or of an actual prize awarded, in several contexts, but more usually that of rewarding victors in athletic and other types of contests. In the Classical World, woollen fillets and wreaths were often used to denote victory; these are included within the term as well as the giving of valuable objects such as metal vessels. The term 'classical games' or 'education' etc. should also be used to indicate the context where appropriate. For lottery prizes, see 'gambling/gaming'.

Label: procession
Scope note: For political marches, see 'march/demomnstration'.

Label: propaganda
Scope note: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, usually political or religious. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

Label: proverb
Scope note: Use for works illustrating popular wisdom, proverbs, etc.

Label: punishment
Scope note: This covers all forms of punishment, such as pillory, etc.

Label: pyramid
Scope note: See also the term 'tomb/mauseoleum'.

Label: queen maya's dream
Scope note: Before the Buddha was born, the Queen his mother dreamed of a white elephant. This dream heralded the birth of either a great king or a wise and pure sage.

Label: ragamala
Scope note: Ragamala are paintings inspired by raga (Indian music), ragini are a modification of a raga.

Label: rakan
Scope note: A disciple of Buddha.

Label: religion/belief
Scope note: Use the terms 'baptism', 'marriage', etc., for religious ceremonies, rather than religion.

Label: religious object
Scope note: To include tripods, mitres, etc. See also cross (under symbol).

Label: religious propaganda
Scope note: The subject refers to the systematic propagation (positive or negative) of information, ideas or behaviour, in this case religious. It is used mainly for posters but is applicable to any type of object such as vessels. The subject propaganda should be distinguished from political satires and standard advertisements (advertising is also a Subject).

Label: restoring the blind man to sight
return of the holy family from egypt
road
Scope note: Use this term sparingly.

Label: rock/mineral
Scope note: For specific geological samples.

Label: roman amphitheatre/arena
Scope note: Roman amphitheatres (also called arenas) were ovoid structures used for entertainment and spectacles, including gladiatorial and animal combats and mock battles. The best-known examples include the amphitheatres in: Arles, Bosra, Beneventum, Bordeaux, Capua, El Djem, Leptis Magna, Nîmes, Pozzuoli, Pula; Rome (Colosseum), Trier, Verona. See also the term 'classical theatre/odeon'.

Label: rowing
Scope note: Remember also to enter named boat races, e.g. Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race, in As.Event.

Label: royal/imperial
Scope note: Neither this term, nor its Narrow Terms, should be used in P&D.

Label: sailor
Scope note: To cover all naval ranks, e.g. admirals, etc.

Label: saint/martyr
Scope note: For images of saints and martyrs, and scenes from their lives, when not covered by the New Testament or 'Christ' categories. Only in the case of `Acts of Apostles' should the term 'saint/martyr' be double-keyed when relevant (i.e. in most cases).

Label: samurai
Scope note: The term should not be used in P&D.

Label: satire
Scope note: Use for any satirical subject. N.B. for P&D, enter the subject 'satire' for ANY print which is satirical, even if it duplicates the object name 'satirical print'.

Label: satyr
Scope note: According to the OED, a faun is god or demigod worshipped by shepherds and farmers, and identified with the Greek Pan wheraes a satyr is a woodland god or demon, partly human and partly animal, supposed to be the companions of Bacchus.

Label: school
Scope note: Use for scenes of teaching. Do not use for riding schools (where horses and riders are being schooled); for this use equestrian. See also school/university/college for architecture.

Label: school/university/college building
Scope note: Use for views of school, university, college, etc. buildings. Do not use for riding schools (where horses and riders are being schooled); for this use equestrian. See also school for scenes of education.

Label: sea animal
Scope note: Use this term for sea animals which are not covered by the main categories of animals listed.

Label: seasons
Scope note: Use for representations of the seasons (see 'Time/Seasons' for allegorical representations).

Label: serpent
Scope note: Do not use this term for depictions of non-mythical snakes, use 'reptile' instead.

Label: servant/domestic worker
Scope note: See also domestic life.

Label: shop
Scope note: See also the term 'market/bazzar'.

Label: shunga
Scope note: This term should only be used if it has also been entered as an object name.

Label: sibyl
Scope note: The name 'asssociated Name 'Cumaean Sibyl' should also be entere in the Associated Name field, where appropriate.

Label: singerie
Scope note: Monkeys engaged in human activity.

Label: single combat
Scope note: The term is used for a representation of an encounter or fight between two combatants, usually armed, in a military context. If the single combat occurs as part of a battle scene, the term 'battle' is used instead (or as an additional Subject) depending on the emphasis of the representation. See also the Subject 'duel'. For gladiatorial combats use that term instead.of 'single combat'. In the case of Amazonomachy, Gigantomachy or Centauromachy use those terms instead of 'single combat' in all cases.

Label: siren
Scope note: Enchantresses or sea nymphs, commonly two or three in number, and often represented as birds with women's heads; their fantastic songs caused those seafarers who heard them to become mad or to land and be devoured.

Label: skating
Scope note: Includes ice-skating and roller-skating.

Label: smoking
Scope note: The term is for smoking tobacco, opium or other substances.

Label: snow
Scope note: Prints & Drawings use seasons.

Label: soldier
Scope note: The Subject term 'soldier' is entered for images of sentinels, even though they are not always military.

Label: south and south east asian myth/legend
Scope note: The term is used for illustrations of the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Life of K???a, Jaimini Bharata, Markandeya Purana, etc. 'Ramayana' and 'Mahabharata' are entered in Associated Title.

Label: spinner/spinning
Scope note: This term is under three Broad Terms as the activity can occur in different contexts, professional or leisure.

Label: sport/pastime
Scope note: See also hunting/shooting and fisherman/fishing, as these subjects include hunting and fishing in sporting and non-sporting contexts.

Label: stable
Scope note: If the stable is part of a farm, use 'farm'.

Label: storm
Scope note: To include hurricanes, blizzards etc.

Label: street-scene
Scope note: This term should not be used for Prints & Drawings.

Label: street-trader
Scope note: The specific trade or occupation should also be entered as a Subject, if known, and if listed as a Narrow Term of TRADE/OCCUPATION.

Label: student
Scope note: The term applies to any student. For an art-student at an academy, use 'art academy' an an additional subject, for other art-students, use 'artistic life' as the additional term.

Label: swastika
Scope note: Swastika (Sanskrit svástika) is an ancient symbol of good luck used by many cultures from c. 3000 BC onwards. It remains widely used in India and as a religious symbol in Hinduism, Buddhism and Jainism. In the West, the symbol is stigmatised by its iconic association with Nazi Germany.

Label: swimming
Scope note: Use when the emphasis is on the activity of swimming, rather than, eg.: a beach scene.

Label: symbol
Scope note: The term should also be used also for Renaissance imprese and similar subjects.

Label: symposium
Scope note: A convivial meeting for drinking, music, and intellectual discussion among the ancient Greeks or Romans.

Label: tantric
Scope note: A subject which refers to ideas expounded in the Indian texts known as the Tantras. These ideas often equate microcosm with macrocosm, and sexual with cosmic.

Label: teachings of christ
Scope note: To include proverbial sayings.

Label: temporary architecture
Scope note: Includes catafalques, triumphal entry constructions, settings for fireworks displays, etc.

Label: temptation of mara
Scope note: Whilst Sakyamundi was meditating under the Bodhi tree, Mara, the Evil One, tried to prevent the boddhisattva from gaining enlightenment. First he sent his three daughters to try and seduce and distract Sakyamundi. He was not distracted. As they approached him, they aged and withered, which angered their father greatly. After this insult, Mara send his hoards against the meditating sage. However, all the weapons that were directed at him turned to harmless flowers.

Label: tenaga
Scope note: Mythical Chinese fisherman 'Long Arms'.

Label: tent/encampment
Scope note: The term 'encampment' in this non-military context is defined as the temporary quarters, formed by tents, vehicles, etc., occupied by a body of nomads or men on the march, travellers, etc. or a lodging in tents, etc.

Label: teutonic/norse legend
Scope note: Examples include the Edda, the Nibelungen legend and the gods of Norse mythology.

Label: textile
Scope note: Use for detailed examples, or designs. Use appropriate related term for the manufacture of textiles, and 'costume' where relevant. NB. This subject also includes designs or studies for textiles.

Label: the ascetics
Scope note: The Buddha met the ascetics in the forests and trained with them for many years before he learned that true enlightenment comes from the middle way.

Label: the birth of sakyamuni
Scope note: The Buddha was born on the roadside beneath a sala tree. The Queen stood beneath a tree holding the branches above her head, and the baby was born from her left side. The baby could walk straight away, and with each step a lotus appeared beneath his foot.

Label: theatre/opera house
Scope note: The term refers to the buildings; see also theatre/theatrical life, and classical theatre/odeon for classical buildings.

Label: theatre/theatrical life
Scope note: The term should be used for performance and other aspects of theatrical life. For buildings, use theatre/opera house and for classical theatres, use 'classical theatre/odeon'.

Label: time/seasons
Scope note: Use for allegorical representations of the seasons, months, day and night, etc.

Label: titan/giant
Scope note: This term is used for giants and titans in classical mythology. The name 'Titan' or a more specific name is entered in Associated Name.

Label: tomb/mausoleum
Scope note: See also the term 'pyramid'.

Label: tool/implement
Scope note: If the emphasis is on an activity or occupation, additional Subject terms should be entered.

Label: torii
Scope note: Shinto shrine gateway.

Label: townscape
Scope note: This term should not be used for Prints & Drawings.

Label: trade/industry
Scope note: Trade and industry are defined very broadly here. For example, some of the Narrow Terms (e.g. 'sewing') are examples of trades in the sense of skilled handicrafts.

Label: trade/occupation
Scope note: This category covers cestablished trades and occupations as well as covering different 'types' in society such as 'grisette' or 'dandy' and people adopting or assuming a mode of life such as 'ascetic'. The Narrow terms are used when the emphasis is on the individual, not on the related activity, e.g.: a representation of an actor, rather than a play (which would go under 'theatre' instead). If the person depicted is also a street-trader, enter this term as a Subject as well. N.B. For Prints and Drawings: in the case of named portraits, the trade/occupation of the sitter is not entered in Subject.

Label: travesty
Scope note: Double-key with relevant category of nationality/date costume.

Label: tree/bush
Scope note: See also 'tree of life'.

Label: tributary/tribute
Scope note: The term should be used mainly for people bearing tribute, but not in a biblical context. See also 'tribute money' for the Biblical subject.

Label: trident
Scope note: Ask about trisula. Asia.

Label: triton
Scope note: If the mythological individual Triton is represented, not just a 'triton', also enter Triton in Associated Name.

Label: trophy head
Scope note: The term refers to a motif widely used in pre-Columbian art.

Label: tughra
Scope note: In mediaeval Arabic and Ottoman Turkish orthography the tughra is a calligraphic emblem of Turkish rulers, from the time of the chiefs of the Oghuz to the Seljuqs and succeeding rulers in Persia, the Mamluks and the Ottoman sultans. In Ottoman practice it became in effect the emblem of the state.

Label: tunnel
Scope note: The term includes tunnels carved into rockfaces.

Label: uki-e
Scope note: A perspective picture particularly relating to townscapes or building interiors. This term must be entered both as Object Name and Subject.

Label: under the bodhi tree
Scope note: The Buddha sat beneath the Bodhi tree, a banyan or pipal tree, meditated and gained enlightenment. In some depictions a Naga rises up behind him to protect him.

Label: vajra
Scope note: A thunderbolt symbol in Buddhist iconography.

Label: vessantara jataka
Scope note: The last of the ten great Jataka stories (Sakyamuni Buddha's previous lives) that is associated with the virtue of generosity.

Label: virgin and child
Scope note: For images with only the Virgin and Child, no other biblical figures present. See also Holy family, etc.

Label: virgin mary
Scope note: Use for pious images. Do not use for scenes from the life of the Virgin which are covered by New Testament categories, such as VISITATION or NATIVITY, for example.

Label: virtues and vices
Scope note: These are generally: the three Theological Virtues (Faith, Hope and Charity) and the four Cardinal Virtues (Prudence, Temperance, Fortitude and Justice) and the seven Vices/Sins (Pride, Envy, Sloth, Anger, Covetousness, Gluttony and Lust) although they vary. For depictions of misers, see the Description field.

Label: viticulture
Scope note: For all the stages of wine production.

Label: waka
Scope note: Japanese thirty one syllable classical or classical style poem.

Label: washerwoman/washerman
Scope note: The term is used for professional washerwomen and washermen as well as for others washing clothes, etc.

Label: water supply
Scope note: See also the terms: 'well', 'cistern' and 'fountain'.

Label: water-carrier
Scope note: If the subject is a water-seller, that term is used instead of water-carrier.

Label: water-collection/carrying
Scope note: The term should be used for scenes with people drawing water from wells, rivers, etc. and carrying it.

Label: weaver/weaving
Scope note: This term is under three Broad Terms as the activity can occur in different contexts, professional or leisure.

Label: well
Scope note: See also the term 'water supply'.

Label: wild man/woman
Scope note: Mythical figures said to inhabit the forests of Central Europe, often represented on coats-of-arms. Double-key with 'heraldry' as necessary.

Label: willow
Scope note: This term is restricted to Asia, where it has iconographic significance (e.g. an attribute of a boddhisattva).

Label: women/feminism
Scope note: For feminist subjects and others relating specifically to women. Enter additional Subject terms as necessary, such as 'politics'.

Label: workshop
Scope note: It is assumed that most workshop scenes are interiors.

Label: wrestling/wrestler
Scope note: If the event is represented in a classical context, the additional Subject term 'classical games' is entered. See also the additional Subject term 'gymnasium/palaistra'.

Label: yaksa/yaksi
Scope note: Minor deity (male and female) associated with natural features, especially trees. Most commonly encountered in early historic Indian religion. The male (yaksa) is usually depicted as heavily built, while the female (yaksi) is curvaceous and associated with fertility.

Label: yi-dam
Scope note: The term refers to a depiction of male and female deities in sexual union.

Label: zodiac
Scope note: Individual zodiacal signs are also entered as Associated Names.
